author: BFMTV
title: Angleterre : Battu par West Ham, Arsenal laisse sa place de leader √† Liverpool
text:
AFP Angleterre : Battu par West Ham, Arsenal laisse sa place de leader √† Liverpool Lire l'article complet AFP 29 d√©cembre 2023 √† 1:14 AM Le milieu de terrain d'Arsenal Declan Rice tacle l'attaquant de West Ham Jarrod Bowen, le 28 d√©cembre 2023 en championnat d'Angleterre √† Londres (HENRY NICHOLLS)
Liverpool reste sur le tr√¥ne de la Premier League apr√®s la contre-performance de son d√©sormais dauphin, Arsenal, battu √† l'Emirates Stadium par West Ham (2-0) jeudi en conclusion d‚Äôune 19e journ√©e qui aura vu perdre trois des cinq √©quipes de t√™te.
En plus des Gunners, Tottenham a √©t√© battu √† Brighton (4-2) alors que le troisi√®me Aston Villa avait c√©d√© en fin de match mardi √† Manchester United (3-2).
Cinq jours apr√®s avoir accroch√© les Reds √† Anfield Road (1-1), Arsenal a contre toute attente c√©d√© face √† l'√©quipe qui l'avait √©limin√©e de la Coupe de la Ligue d√©but novembre. Les Hammers ont donn√© raison √† l'analyse de leur entra√Æneur David Moyes, qui assurait avant le match que cette ann√©e √©tait la meilleure de l'histoire du club, avec notamment un triomphe en Ligue Europa Conf√©rence.
Ils n'ont pas conc√©d√© la moindre occasion dans la premi√®re demi-heure de jeu, et m√™me marqu√© peu avant le quart d'heure apr√®s une mauvaise appr√©ciation de Gabriel Magalhaes, qui a profit√© √† Tomas Soucek (0-1, 13e). L'ancien d√©fenseur Lillois a √©galement perdu un duel a√©rien d√©cisif en seconde p√©riode face √† Konstantinos Mavropanos, suite √† un corner de Ward-Prowse (2-0, 55e).
Souvent efficaces face au but depuis le d√©but de la saison, les Gunners ont cette fois manqu√© de r√©alisme avec Saka (30e, 42e), Martinelli (37e), Gabriel Jesus (66e) puis Trossard dans le dernier quart d'heure. Le score aurait pu √™tre plus cruel si Benrahma avait transform√© son penalty dans le temps additionnel.
"Quand on tire trente fois au but, qu'on a 2,6 expected goals et qu'on a autant de situations dans la surface de r√©paration, on n'imagine pas qu'il faille faire beaucoup plus pour marquer un but et pour gagner ce match", a affirm√© Mikel Arteta en conf√©rence de presse.
Nomm√© il y a quatre ans, l'entra√Æneur des Gunners n'a pas comment√© le manque de profondeur de banc, alors que les entr√©es successives de Smith Rowe, Nelson et Nketiah n'ont pas permis de faire la diff√©rence en seconde p√©riode.
Lire la suite Arsenal compte deux points de retard sur Liverpool, alors que West Ham, 6e, est √† l'affut des places europ√©ennes, √† trois points de Tottenham et quatre points de Manchester City, vainqueur mardi √† Everton (3-1) et qui compte un match de plus √† disputer.
- Tottenham rechute lourdement -
Peu avant, Tottenham avait s√©v√®rement rechut√© sur le terrain de Brighton (4-2) et rat√© l'occasion de se rapprocher de la t√™te du championnat. Tottenham √©tait pourtant la meilleure √©quipe √† l'ext√©rieur avant cette rencontre et finit la premi√®re moiti√© de saison sur une note n√©gative, malgr√© une bonne cinqui√®me place au classement, √† un point de Manchester City.
Meilleurs ces derni√®res semaines apr√®s un mois de novembre catastrophique sur le plan des r√©sultats, les Spurs ont montr√© un visage inhabituel avec beaucoup de passivit√©, comme sur cette action individuelle de Joao Pedro qui a pu passer en revue quatre joueurs et donner une balle en or √† Jack Hinshelwood, d√©marqu√© √† l'entr√©e de la surface de r√©paration (1-0, 11e).
Entre plusieurs occasions nettes pour Brighton (17e, 32e, 45e), le m√™me Joao Pedro allait ensuite transformer deux p√©nalties (23e, 75e), avec entre-temps un frappe puissante de Pervis Estupinan dans la lucarne oppos√©e de Vicario (63e). Alejo Veliz (81e) et Ben Davies (85e) ont r√©duit le score, trop tard pour faire douter les Seagulls.
Brighton se repositionne √† la huiti√®me place, √† six points de la premi√®re place europ√©enne.
str/bvo/roc
TENDANCE Russie: des personnalit√©s participent √† une f√™te "presque nues" et suscitent l'indignation BFMTV G√©rard Depardieu doit √™tre consid√©r√© comme "un malade", Marl√®ne Jobert sort du silence Purepeople Victoria Abril accus√©e d'agressions sexuelles par Lucie Lucas : un acteur de Clem la d√©fend, "elle est assur√©e de mon soutien inconditionnel" Purebreak Nicolas Sarkozy et Carla Bruni : Leur sublime ch√¢teau au coeur d'une sombre affaire, un procureur de la R√©publique saisi Purepeople "J'ai √©t√© t√©moin..." : Lucie Lucas fait de nouvelles r√©v√©lations apr√®s ses accusations contre Victoria Abril Purebreak

author: Karen Pilarski - Freeman Staff
title: Taking WCTC to the next level | Oconomowoc News | gmtoday.com
text:
Waukesha County Technical College President and CEO Rich Barnhouse‚Äôs career aspirations were in flex until he started graduate school.
As a graduate assistant Barnhouse got to see the inner workings of a university and felt it was really interesting. Barnhouse wasn‚Äôt one to sit on his laurels and continued to seek out his life passion. According to Barnhouse, he is constantly developing as a person and leader.
It is higher education where he can see how he and WCTC impacts each student who walks through its doors.
The Freeman asked Barnhouse questions about education, leadership and the challenges faced in the industry. Here are his responses.
The FREEMAN: What inspired you to go into this field?
Rich Barnhouse: It was by accident. My goal was to get out of school as quickly as possible and never go back. I grew up in a manufacturing family and wanted to get into the workforce as quickly as possible. I finished my undergrad, and at that point I had thought about working in the family business, but I decided to go to grad school. When I was getting my master‚Äôs, I was a graduate assistant. In that role, you get to see all the behind-the-scenes inner workings of a university and I remember thinking it was really interesting. I finished my master‚Äôs degree and had a job offer with the Detroit Red Wings; I also had a job opportunity at Rice University in Houston. I wanted to work for the Red Wings, but I was really, really interested in higher education and the impact it has on the country.
FREEMAN: What skills and experience have shaped your career?
Barnhouse: I think your skills come from your experience. When I was in grad school at Central Michigan University, I had a staff of 20-30 undergrads. I was kind of finding my way in leading and managing. I think I stole leadership traits, leadership style, inflection and tone in my voice, and mannerisms from leaders who I thought were awesome. Most of them didn‚Äôt know that I was doing it, but I was watching them: watching how people responded to them ‚Äî and watching how people didn‚Äôt respond to others. Leadership is an ongoing laboratory where you‚Äôre constantly watching and trying to figure out how to inspire and influence people toward a goal.
FREEMAN: Many colleges and universities are struggling. What are the keys to WCTC‚Äôs success?
Barnhouse: Step one is to just make the decision to not be average, and we are not going to be the status quo. Your mission can‚Äôt be your goal; your mission is your baseline and you have to shoot above your mission. And you‚Äôve got to be able to take risks. Listen to the businesses, industry and employers. Listen to the taxpayers.
And then do what they‚Äôre asking for by using your professional skill, ability and knowledge to pull it off. For us, we‚Äôre defying gravity, but it‚Äôs not by accident. We‚Äôre looking at the horizon: we‚Äôre looking as far as we can, and we‚Äôre working back from there.
FREEMAN: What are the challenges?
Barnhouse: One of the big challenges in higher education is that there was this path for an administrator and playbook for how to run the operations of a college or university ‚Äî that doesn‚Äôt apply today.
Higher education is having to evolve and adopt more private sector business practices and principles. It‚Äôs uncomfortable for higher education in general because it‚Äôs a different model. How we balance that, while keeping true to higher education‚Äôs mission, is a line that we have to straddle on a daily basis for the health of the institution. It has become a job requirement, which maybe it wasn‚Äôt for a college president a decade ago.
FREEMAN: What is the most rewarding part of being in this type of work?
Barnhouse: You can actually see lives change. It‚Äôs palpable.
Think about it like this: Education is the only discipline or field that makes all other disciplines or fields possible. It‚Äôs a noble pursuit.
It‚Äôs truly an honor and a privilege to be in a position where you‚Äôre leading a college. Seeing the impact at the individual level, when somebody thought that they‚Äôd never be able to accomplish something and they do ‚Äî it‚Äôs incredible. And it changes families; it changes communities.
FREEMAN: Describe yourself as a leader.
Barnhouse: I would say as a leader, I‚Äôm in constant development mode. I‚Äôm miles and miles away from the kind of leader I want to be.
FREEMAN: How do you assess a program to determine if it needs to grow or change?
Barnhouse: Step one is to listen to employers. Every program at WCTC has an advisory committee composed of business and industry pros who help guide the curriculum. Historically, in education, faculty have relied on a textbook, and that textbook is often out of date by the time it‚Äôs published since things change so quickly.
Sure, we teach with textbooks, but these advisory committees help us understand what is changing in the industry in real time. We are talking to the people who are on the floor, in the back office, leading these organizations. We also ask business and industry to tell us when a program is no longer needed. We‚Äôll teach it out so students can finish, then we‚Äôll sunset the program. We‚Äôre not going to carry legacy programs that industry doesn‚Äôt want; we‚Äôre teaching in a very evolutionary and forward-thinking way.
FREEMAN: What other programs are gaining traction?
Barnhouse: We will be launching the new Manufacturing Integration Engineering Technology associate degree in fall 2025, and we are exploring more artificial intelligence programs along with automation specialties. Our liberal arts transfer degrees have become increasingly popular since they began in 2023, and our skilled trades programs remain strong.
We‚Äôve also seen a marked increase in our dual enrollment numbers as younger, high school-age students are looking to save time and money and get out into the workforce sooner.
FREEMAN: As higher education continues to evolve, how does WCTC keep the pulse of what future students want?
Barnhouse: I think, one area where higher education missed the mark for years is that they focused on what they thought 18-year-olds might be interested in ‚Äî but that doesn‚Äôt necessarily correlate with what business and industry want.
To create a program that might increase enrollment because it‚Äôs interesting but not employable is ineffective ‚Äî and that‚Äôs what most colleges do. The most successful program is the program that leads to a wildly successful career. We have been very intentional in developing programs, listening to our stakeholders and meeting their needs. As an institution of higher learning, it is critical for us to maintain strong connections and listen closely to business and industry and see what their specific need is going to be in two, three or five years.
FREEMAN: Why have AI programs at WCTC been so successful?
Barnhouse: The demand from business and industry in Southeastern Wisconsin for AI programming has expanded exponentially.
In addition to our strong existing IT programs, such as Data and Analytics, and Cybersecurity, we really partnered with the right people to build the AI curriculum.
We designed our AI program (degree and certificates) based on the best technology in the world from Intel, the chipmaker, and then made it applicable to business and industry in Southeastern Wisconsin. We built this from scratch.
There are a lot of charlatans out there that take existing IT programs, manipulate the coursework and then call it AI. We developed new coursework that didn‚Äôt exist; it‚Äôs brand new. That‚Äôs what makes us truly a trailblazer.
FREEMAN: What does the future look like for new programs in this field?
Barnhouse: The AI (degree) program we have now is just the start. It was first offered in the fall and it was at capacity, so we had to add more sections. This just goes to show how much this is sought after. We‚Äôre going to develop more and different AI programs, and we‚Äôre also implementing AI throughout the whole institution to help our 1,500 employees become more efficient. In our new Applied AI Lab, we‚Äôre helping entrepreneurs and startups create new, groundbreaking AI products ‚Äî things that don‚Äôt exist in the country, and likely, in the world.
The innovation that will come out of our lab could change the human experience. The future of AI is going to be transformative; we‚Äôre just getting started at WCTC.

author: deccanchronicle.com
title: Claude Arpi | China‚Äôs ‚Äòsalami‚Äô warfare big danger to Himalayas
text:
Claude Arpi | China‚Äôs ‚Äòsalami‚Äô warfare big danger to Himalayas Columnists Claude Arpi 22 Aug 2024 6:40 PM GMT x A portion of a mountain washes away during a landslide, at Dipu Dara near Singtam in Gangtok district, Tuesday, Aug. 20, 2024. The landslide caused damage to the powerhouse of the Teesta Stage V hydroelectric project of the NHPC, according to officials. (PTI Photo) The planet is being churned; and wherever one looks, one sees natural and unnatural (mostly man-made) disasters.
It is not only the multiple landslides that occurred in six villages of Wayanad district of Kerala on July 30, but the entire Himalayan belt is disturbed.
In Wayanad, heavy rains triggered the collapse of hillsides, resulting in torrents of mud, water and boulders cascading down into the valley. Similarly in the Himalayas, particularly in Himachal Pradesh and Uttarakhand or Arunachal Pradesh, tragic incidents such as these are taking place.
In most of the cases, wild development activities have resulted in these mishaps. For example, in Himachal Pradesh, some environmental activists told the Down To Earth magazine that ‚Äúmost incidents of natural disasters that occurred in Himachal Pradesh during the last one year happened around some power (dams) or national highway project‚Äù.
In Uttarakhand, wild construction, not taking into account the capacity of the mountains to sustain new roads, new hotels and millions of tourists, has been one of the factors triggering one tragedy after another.
One basic fact has been forgotten: that mountains are fragile.
Flying over the Himalayan range, one has the impression that the snow-covered ranges and high peaks are massive and seemingly-impenetrable mountains; however, on the ground, the Himalayas are in grave danger.
For millennia the Himalayan passes have been criss-crossed by adventurers, pilgrims, traders, monks or holy men looking for a mythic paradise upon earth, or simply good business; however, through all that time the environment was not disturbed.
Another factor has to be taken into consideration is the militarisation of the Himalayan range, and for this India cannot be held responsible.
The finger must be pointed clearly at our northern neighbour.
For centuries, life went on as usual, but in 1950 the troops of China‚Äôs People‚Äôs Liberation Army (PLA) marched into Tibet. The military balance of the peaceful plateau as well as the ecological equilibrium quickly started to change.
During the following years, thousands of Tibetans managed to escape their colonised land and take refuge to India; it included the Dalai Lama, Tibet‚Äôs religious and temporal leader, who arrived in India in 1959.
Then came October 1962, when Chinese troops attacked India on the Himalayan slopes; from the arid Ladakh region in the west to the dense forests in the north-west, the PLA marched into Indian territory. The conflict was short, just one month, but violent. More than 60 years after the event, it is still deeply engraved in the Indian psyche.
It had incalculable consequences for the mountains and though the passes were closed, trade and pilgrimage routes stopped and communications were cut between northern India and the Tibetan plateau. India now had a bully instead of a friend as a neighbour.
At the beginning, very few worried about the environment and even less about climate change. But the Chinese occupation slowly started to have disastrous consequences for the Himalayan ecology.
Today, it is not only India who is under threat of the Chinese ‚Äúsalami tactics‚Äù (taking over a few kilometres of territory at a time).
On August 23, 2023, China released a new ‚Äústandard map‚Äù. The map included Taiwan and parts of the maritime zones of the Philippines, Vietnam, Brunei, Indonesia, and Malaysia. It added the tenth dash to its existing nine-dash line claim in the South China Sea‚Ä¶ and of course Arunachal Pradesh and the Aksai Chin area.
Interestingly, the map included the small Bolshoy Ussuriysky island, though in 2005, Russia and China had agreed that the island would be split in half and the border would run in its centre.
On May 17, 2024, the South China Morning Post in an opinion piece said that ‚ÄúChina must act fast to reclaim ‚Äòlost territories‚Äô from Russia‚Äù. A hundred years ago, a treaty between the then USSR and China had abolished the so-called Czarist unequal treaties, it noted, and said: ‚ÄúNow, with Russian President Vladimir Putin bogged down in the Ukraine war, it may be the best time for Beijing.‚Äù
Another recent example of Chinese aggressiveness, from August 2 to 4, some Japanese fighter planes had to scramble to cope with a intrusion into Japanese airspace over the Sea of Okhotsk, the Sea of Japan, the East China Sea and the Pacific Ocean.
Examples could be multiplied. India, like several other countries, has no alternative but to defend itself.
As a result, the Himalayas have become one of the most militarised regions in the world. Despite several bilateral agreements between India and China, in May 2020, China started practicing ‚Äúsalami‚Äù slicing in five different areas of Ladakh, the high plateau in north-western India.
Why open new fronts in that arid mountain desert?
Many believe that one general, in search of promotion, had suggested some ‚Äúsmall‚Äù operation to President Xi Jinping. These few kilometres here and there would give strategic depth to the PLA.
India reacted swiftly, at the cost of spending four winters at 15,000 feet, often with temperatures at minus 40 degrees Celsius.
Each army has today between 60,000 and 70,000 troops posted at the Line of Actual Control (LAC). China and India then began to frenetically develop the infrastructure on their respective sides. The immediate collateral damage was to the environment; this is compounded by climate change and wild tourism development.
On July 25, India‚Äôs external affairs minister S. Jaishankar met China‚Äôs foreign minister Wang Yi. Mr Jaishankar underlined the need for ‚Äúfull respect‚Äù of the LAC; ultimately, both sides agreed on giving ‚Äústrong guidance for disengagement‚Äù. It is, however, doubtful that it will translate in troops reduction on the ground.
The degradation of the Himalayan environment is obviously due to several other factors too, but the militarisation triggered by China‚Äôs hegemonic tendencies has brought incalculable harm to the fragile eco-system.
A solution had been proposed by the Dalai Lama in 1989 in his Five-Point Peace Plan: the whole of Tibet, including the eastern provinces of Kham and Amdo, should be transformed into a zone of ‚ÄúAhimsa‚Äù, meaning a state of peace and non-violence.
Unfortunately, this dream seems much more distant today than 35 years ago; when the Dalai Lama had explained: ‚ÄúThe establishment of a peace zone in Tibet would require the withdrawal of Chinese troops and military installations from the country, which would enable India also to withdraw troops and military installations from the Himalayan regions bordering Tibet.‚Äù
A ‚ÄúZone of Ahimsa‚Äù would be a great boon for the Himalayan environment, but for the time being, it may remain a dream.
( Source : Deccan Chronicle )

author: @thetechgame
title: Call of Duty: Black Ops 6 Players Demand Return of Popular Playlists - The Tech Game
text:
Though Black Ops 6 has been a hit for many gamers so far, it appears that Treyarch's choices regarding playlists is negatively impacting some fans' enjoyment of the title. Though some may value map variety when it comes to multiplayer matches, others want to get as much out of maps like Stakeout and Nuketown and specific playlists as they possibly can, with the latter crowd being the one that is frustrated with recen playlist adjustments.
Reddit users Wraithhh and Jdammworldwide are among this group of Black Ops 6 players who want Stakeout 24/7 and 10v10 back, and they're trying to make sure that Treyarch hears their demands. These Black Ops 6 players seem to be in agreement that many of the maps just don't have a proper flow during regular multiplayer gameplay, and have expressed a strong preference for Stakeout since its hectic nature makes the lack of flow less apparent.
[Bring Back Stakeout 24/7!!]
by[u/Wraithhh]in[blackops6]
[Bring back 10v10]
by[u/Jdammworldwide]in[blackops6]
Since Treyarch seems especially attentive to player requests for this title, as it has already made major changes across the board based on fan feedback, gamers are also expressing their wishes for 10v10 Moshpit, which many think just adds to the overall experience. Knowing that it's possible, but not having the option to play 10v10 in Black Ops 6 seems pointless to some fans.
Posted:
Related Forum:
[Call of Duty Forum](/Forums/f=268/call-of-duty-forum.html)
Source: https://gamerant.com/call-duty-black-ops-6-stakeout-10v10-playlist-removal-complaint/

author: EFE
title: Una ONG denuncia la muerte de 14 personas en una z√≥diac al sur de Canarias - La Opini√≥n de A Coru√±a
text: Al menos catorce personas han muerto ahogadas en una z√≥diac cuyos ocupantes llevan pidiendo auxilio desde las 14.00 horas de este jueves desde un punto del Atl√°ntico situado a unos 55 kil√≥metros de Cabo Bojador, en la costa marroqu√≠ del S√°hara Occidental, al sur de [Canarias](https://www.laopinioncoruna.es/tags/islas-canarias/), porque su barca se desinfla y se hunden. Es la denuncia que realiza la activista Helena Maleno, fundadora de Caminando Fronteras, ONG que lleva toda la tarde de este jueves en contacto con los n√°ufragos y que ha transmitido su posici√≥n a las autoridades espa√±olas y marroqu√≠es para que movilicen medios de rescate. Por la localizaci√≥n del incidente, ha asumido la emergencia Rabat. Maleno ha facilitado a EFE una foto enviada por los supervivientes que todav√≠a siguen a flote, una imagen nocturna y borrosa en la que se ve a entre seis y siete personas sentadas a horcajadas sobre un flotador de una neum√°tica, doblado y medio deshinchado. Y tambi√©n un audio que le ha remitido una de las ocupantes de la patera. En √©l se escucha a una mujer decir en franc√©s: "Estamos aqu√≠, Helena. Soy una mujer embarazada de nueve meses, estoy en el flotador (de la z√≥diac). Todos los chicos del medio (de la embarcaci√≥n) han desaparecido, la gente est√° desapareciendo, hasta ahora no hemos visto a la Marina". "Toda la gente est√° desapareciendo. ¬°Por favor ay√∫dennos, ay√∫dennos! ¬°Estamos aqu√≠, ay√∫dennos! Estamos sentados as√≠ en el flotador (se refiere a la imagen que adjunta con el audio). Es muy peligroso, el agua est√° entrando", se lamenta la mujer Helena Maleno ha explicado a EFE que, seg√∫n la informaci√≥n que han recabado sobre esa neum√°tica, se trata de un grupo de 58 personas que salieron el mi√©rcoles desde la costa del Sahara hacia Canarias y que ahora se encuentran al suroeste de Cabo Bojador. Entre ellos, a√±ade, hay siete mujeres (incluyendo a la embarazada) y dos ni√±os. La portavoz de Caminando Fronteras denuncia que, hasta el momento, Marruecos no ha hecho llegar ayuda a los ocupantes de esa neum√°tica, ni tampoco Salvamento Mar√≠timo espa√±ol ha intervenido. Por eso, expresa su temor a que ocurra lo mismo que el 21 de junio, cuando varias personas murieron al hundirse una z√≥diac al sur de Gran Canaria despu√©s de pasar toda la noche esperando a que llegara una patrullera de Marruecos, porque la emergencia la hab√≠a asumido el Centro de Coordinaci√≥n de Salvamento de Rabat. Y ello, a pesar de que un barco de rescate espa√±ol hab√≠a estado a solo una hora de distancia de navegaci√≥n de ellos, socorriendo a otra patera, cuando ya se conoc√≠an sus coordenadas. Ese suceso dio lugar una denuncia de la Fiscal√≠a de Canarias por presunto delito de omisi√≥n del deber de socorro contra los responsables del operativo en Espa√±a, denuncia que desde este verano instruye un Juzgado de Las Palmas de Gran Canaria, que ha declarado secretas las actuaciones.

author: Caroline Vale
title: Dor de ouvido no ver√£o: saiba como prevenir e tratar esse inc√¥modo de vez
text:
Ao contr√°rio do que muita gente pensa, as otites n√£o desaparecem com o fim dos dias mais frios. O ver√£o, com as suas atividades em praia ou piscina, al√©m de banhos mais frequentes, pode representar perigo para a sa√∫de auricular .
Como evitar e tratar a dor de ouvido que surge no ver√£o - iStock/Miguel Angel Flores Por√©m, com aten√ß√£o e alguns cuidados simples, √© poss√≠vel evitar os inc√¥modos, de acordo com a otorrinolaringologista do Hospital S√£o Vicente , Mariele Bolzan Lovato.
O que causa a dor de ouvido no ver√£o? Tem como evitar? Segundo a profissional, essas queixas geralmente est√£o associadas a uma rolha de cera j√° presente no ouvido e que, ao entrar em contato com a √°gua, fica l√≠quida e ‚Äútranca‚Äù o canal.
Essa cera, associada a um ac√∫mulo de √°gua, pode causar uma inflama√ß√£o no ouvido: ‚Äú√© o que chamamos de otite externa, que pode causar dor‚Äù, explica.
Quem sempre se incomoda com esse ac√∫mulo de cera, orienta a m√©dica do Hospital S√£o Vicente, deve buscar um otorrinolaringologista antes da temporada do ver√£o para fazer a remo√ß√£o preventiva e evitar problemas.
‚ú® Facilite sua vida com dicas de qualidade. Inscreva-se no nosso canal da Catraca Livre no WhatsApp. üì¢ Por√©m, vale esclarecer que quem costuma ficar muito tempo exposto √† √°gua do mar ou da piscina estar√°, de fato, mais suscet√≠vel a infec√ß√µes . ‚ÄúSe n√£o for poss√≠vel reduzir esse tempo, assim que sair da √°gua, √© importante inclinar a cabe√ßa para o lado e tentar secar por fora do canal auditivo com o maior cuidado poss√≠vel, preferencialmente com uma toalha limpa‚Äù, indica.
Quais s√£o os sintomas para se atentar? Se por algum descuido, aparecerem sintomas como dor de ouvido, ouvido entupido, coceira intensa, febre, diminui√ß√£o da audi√ß√£o, zumbido ou sensa√ß√£o de press√£o e dor de cabe√ßa, √© fundamental buscar ajuda.
As otites externas, infec√ß√£o do canal auditivo externo que vai do t√≠mpano ao exterior da cabe√ßa, s√£o as mais comuns no ver√£o e podem incluir, ainda, entre os sintomas, uma secre√ß√£o amarelada ou marrom.
Tratamento Caso apare√ßam esses sintomas, √© necess√°rio consultar um otorrinolaringologista. ‚ÄúNa maioria das vezes √© necess√°rio um antibi√≥tico em gotas diretamente no ouvido‚Äù, conta a m√©dica.
‚ÄúMas diab√©ticos ou pessoas com baixa imunidade, em tratamento oncol√≥gico, por exemplo, podem ter quadros mais graves, com a doen√ßa se espalhando para a orelha, pesco√ßo e para a parte mais interna do ouvido . Nesse caso, pode ser necess√°rio internamento com o uso de antibi√≥ticos na veia‚Äù, completa.
O profissional far√° o diagn√≥stico por meio de um exame visual e receitar√° o melhor tratamento para cada caso e progress√£o da condi√ß√£o.
A otorrinolaringologista alerta que receitas caseiras nunca devem ser utilizadas, pois podem agravar o problema. Para aliviar a dor, uma op√ß√£o segura √© aplicar uma compressa morna com √°gua na parte externa da orelha.
Tamb√©m na Catraca Livre , veja os sinais da doen√ßa que fez a apresentadora Adriane Galisteu perder 60% da audi√ß√£o .

author: Rebecca Dore
title: Mum Who Cares For Sons With CF Wins Naas Best Dressed
text:
'I'm so delighted! I can't believe it. If I'm being honest with you, we actually just threw ourselves into my nephew's van this morning saying do you know something, we'll go up for the craic,' Limerick mum Mary Woulfe admitted after she kicked off 2024 on a stunning style note.
Thick fog may have descended on Naas Racecourse but the style shone bright and the mother-of-two from Cratloe West in Athea was crowned the winner of the Best Dressed competition.
Today's top videos
Mary, 50, impressed the panel of judges wearing a preowned Zara boucle wine and gold looped yarn trouser suit and a statement red disc fascinator with a large floral detail by Newcastle West-based milliner Siobhan Boyce.
Mary Woulfe from Athea, Co. Limerick, winner of the Naas Racecourse Winter Best Dressed competition. Pic: INPHO/Morgan Treacy She accessorised with a stole reimagined from an old coat which was finished with a gold-toned jewelled brooch, wine drop earrings from Imari Edit Boutique in Listowel, a gold clutch from her friend Tasha O‚ÄôConnor, purple leather gloves and Lodi gold shoes.
It was a last-minute decision to attend the winter racing day at the Kildare track, and she has her nephew Brian to thank for playing an instrumental role.
Mary Woulfe from Athea, Co. Limerick, winner of the Naas Racecourse Winter Best Dressed competition. Pic: INPHO/Morgan Treacy She told EVOKE : 'He was going off to Dublin to meet friends and I texted my friend Tasha and said we said we'd get off at Naas and oh my God, I can't believe I'm actually walking out with the prize.'
Mary is an avid race-goer who loves getting glammed up for the races and there was quite a story behind her winning ensemble.
She explained: 'We're always getting done up and doing this and I had this outfit at home. I had the whole lot for the Listowel Races and I said, "I'll try it again."'
She said that she was 'in shock' to win especially considering the other finalists who she said 'looked just amazing'.
Mary Woulfe from Athea, Co. Limerick, winner of the Naas Racecourse Winter Best Dressed competition. Pic: INPHO/Morgan Treacy Mary won a ‚Ç¨2,000 gift card for Frasers department store at the Whitewater Shopping Centre in Newbridge, a two-night stay in a luxurious suite at Lawlor's of Naas Town Centre Hotel, dinner in Vi‚Äôs Restaurant and ‚ÄòTipsy Afternoon Tea'.
The glamorous runners-up, √Åine Malone from Edenderry and Breda Butler from Thurles, walked away with ‚Ç¨100 Frasers gift cards and afternoon tea at Lawlor‚Äôs Hotel.
Mary Woulfe (centre) from Athea, Co. Limerick, winner of the Naas Racecourse Winter Best Dressed competition runners up from left, √Åine Malone from Edenderry and Breda Butler from Thurles. Pic: NPHO/Morgan Treacy Mary's brocade suit previously belonged to one of the other finalists: Breda Butler (who was crowned Best Dressed at the Curragh in May 2023 in stunning sunny style ).
She purchased the statement suit on the Racewear and Wedding Guest Wear for Sale Facebook page where fashion lovers can buy and sell pre-loved garments.
'I know all the girls going to racing because I go to a lot of them. I always look out for Breda Butler's outfit because her style is amazing.
Mandy Maher, Dee Nix, CEO of Lawlor's Naas Town Centre Hotel, Mary Woulfe and Sarah McDermott at Naas Racecourse. Pic: Supplied 'So I spotted this suit and bought it off to Breda. So we had a great laugh on stage together. When my name was announced she said: 'I want that suit back, Mary!"'
Fashion stylist and model agency owner Mandy Maher was judging alongside Kildare model and influencer Sarah McDermott while the fashion competition was MC-ed by PR boss Aileen O'Brien.
Mandy Maher and Sarah McDermott at Naas Racecourse. Pic: INPHO/Morgan Treacy Mary, who is carer of her sons Robbie and Ryan, relishes the chance to get her glamour on at the races.
'My two boys have cystic fibrosis. I'm a carer at home and my oldest boy has autism as well,' she shared.
'We had a bit of a hard start with Robbie and so I decided to give up work as a dental nurse and I've stayed at home to mind my two boys,' she explained.
Aileen O'Brien, Mandy Maher, Dee Nix, CEO of Lawlor's Naas Town Centre Hotel, Mary Woulfe and Sarah McDermott at Naas Racecourse. Pic: Supplied She said that a new pharmaceutical drug developed for CF, Kaftrio, has changed their lives.
'Our lives have actually changed upside down. They say it's not a cure. It actually is. Their lung function, their weight, everything has been 100 percent and we were told at our last appointment that their bodies are presenting non-CF.'
'The days over the years have been hard. So it is great old craic to get out and meet girls and get dressed up and out of the tracksuit and the sneakers,' Mary shared
Mary Woulfe from Athea, Co. Limerick, winner of the Naas Racecourse Winter Best Dressed competition. Pic: INPHO/Morgan Treacy 'That's how I started [attending best dressed competitions]. I loved meeting up with all the girls, all the same craic goes on and I just can't believe I actually came out on top,' she said.
The day was a 'laugh from start to finish' as she reflected: 'I didn't realise my nephew was bringing the van, trying to change inside the van outside the racecourse, the speed of us!
'He actually went down by where the cars were parked and he got stuck with the mud and the two of us physically had to get out of the van. It was well worth being stuck in the mud!'
Mary Woulfe from Athea, Co. Limerick, winner of the Naas Racecourse Winter Best Dressed competition. Pic: INPHO/Morgan Treacy She revealed she is going to treat her friend Tasha to a shopping spree but she'll be whisking her husband Philip away for the hotel break!
Just one race went to post, with the rest being cancelled due to poor visibility.
The high-class Grade One Lawlor‚Äôs of Naas Novice Hurdle and the rest of the premium races have been rescheduled to run on Friday, January 12. For more information head to the Naas Racecourse website .
See more pictures from the Best Dressed competition below: Michelle Fallon from Offaly at Naas Racecourse. Pic: INPHO/Morgan Treacy Aine Malone from Edenderry and Anne-Marie Corbett from Cork at Naas Racecourse. Pic: INPHO/Morgan Treacy Jamie Lost from Kildare Town at Naas Racecourse. Pic: INPHO/Morgan Treacy Mary Woulfe from Limerick at Naas Racecourse. Pic: INPHO/Morgan Treacy Ann Marie Dunning from Newbridge and Breda Butler from Thurles at Naas Racecourse. Pic: INPHO/Morgan Treacy Geraldine Shalvey from Dublin at Naas Racecourse. Pic: NPHO/Morgan Treacy Liam Moloney, Ireland Honorary Consul to Slovenia with Ljiljana Vidovic and Stanislav Vivovic, Slovenia Ambassador to Ireland, at Naas Racecourse. Pic: INPHO/Morgan Treacy

author: Jon Guttman
title: The Holocaust survivor who became a Medal of Honor recipient
text:
When
Tibor Rubin received the Medal of Honor in 2005, he largely had his sergeant to thank. Said sergeant constantly sent him on missions intended to get him killed. By then, however, Rubin had a history of defying the Reaper.
Born in P√°szt√≥, Hungary, on June 18, 1929, Tibor Rubin was 13 when the Nazis sent him to Mauthausen concentration camp in Austria. He survived 14 months before the U.S. Third Army liberated the camp. His family was less fortunate ‚Äî his stepmother and sister died in Auschwitz and his father perished in Buchenwald.
In 1948 Rubin emigrated to the United States, working first as a shoemaker and then a butcher in New York City. He also strove to fulfill a promise that ‚Äúif the Lord helped me go to America, I‚Äôd join the Army.‚Äù
He failed the language test in 1949 but enlisted after a second try. In July 1950 Private First Class ‚ÄúTed‚Äù Rubin was shipped to Korea as a member of Company I, 8th Regiment, 1st Cavalry Division.
RELATED
There he discovered the persistence of American anti-Semitism, particularly from his sergeant, Arthur Peyton, who made a policy of ‚Äúvolunteering‚Äù him for the most hazardous missions. During one, Rubin defended a hill against waves of attacking North Koreans for 24 hours.
‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt have too much time to get scared,‚Äù he explained afterward, ‚Äúso I went crazy.‚Äù For that and other outstanding actions two of Rubin‚Äôs commanders recommended him for the Medal of Honor, but both officers were subsequently killed and Peyton ‚Äúlost‚Äù the paperwork.
That October the United Nations forces were advancing into North Korea when the Chinese intervened, reversing fortunes in Korea for the second time since the war began. Manning a lone machine gun, Rubin covered his regiment‚Äôs retreat until the ammunition ran out. He was shot in the chest, arm and leg, and was captured.
It wasn‚Äôt until April 20, 1953, that Rubin was released in a prisoner of war exchange. Although sick and weak, he claimed that Chinese treatment, harsh though it was, was a cakewalk compared to Mauthausen, from which he‚Äôd developed survival techniques that came into play again, such as stealing food and medicine from his captors or using maggots to treat gangrenous wounds, all of which he did for fellow POWs as ‚Äúmitzvahs‚Äù (good deeds).
Learning that he was not yet an American citizen, the Chinese repeatedly offered to repatriate him to Hungary if he wished. Given the oppressive Communist regime there, Rubin declined.
After his honorable discharge with two Purple Hearts, Rubin attained citizenship and settled in Long Beach, California, mainly working at a liquor store with his brother Emery. After meeting him at later reunions, however, veterans of I Company and men who knew him in captivity began a campaign to get Rubin the recognition they thought he‚Äôd long deserved.
Finally, in 2005, President George W. Bush presented him with the Medal of Honor, with a citation that described all he‚Äôd been witnessed to have done:
‚ÄúCorporal Tibor Rubin distinguished himself by extraordinary heroism during the period from July 23, 1950, to April 20, 1953, while serving as a rifleman with I Company, 8th Cavalry Regiment, 1st Cavalry Division in the Republic of Korea. While his unit was retreating to the Pusan Perimeter, Corporal Rubin was assigned to stay behind to keep open the Taegu-Pusan Road link used by his withdrawing unit.
During the ensuing battle, overwhelming numbers of North Korean troops assaulted a hill defended solely by Corporal Rubin. He inflicted a staggering number of casualties on the attacking force during this 24-hour personal battle, single-handedly slowing the enemy advance and allowing the 8th Cavalry Regiment to complete its withdrawal successfully.
Following the breakout from the Pusan Perimeter, the 8th Cavalry Regiment proceeded northward and advanced into North Korea. During the advance he helped capture several hundred North Korean soldiers. On October 30, 1950, Chinese forces attacked his unit at Unsan, North Korea, during a massive nighttime assault. That night and throughout the next day, he manned a .30 caliber machine gun at the south end of the unit‚Äôs line after three gunners became casualties. He continued to man his machine gun until his ammunition was exhausted. His determined stand slowed the pace of the enemy advance in his sector, permitting the remnants of his unit to retreat southward.
As the battle raged, Corporal Rubin was severely wounded and captured by the Chinese. Choosing to remain in the prison camp despite offers from the Chinese to return him to his native Hungary, Corporal Rubin disregarded his own personal safety and immediately began sneaking out of the camp at night in search of food for his comrades. Breaking into enemy storehouses and gardens, he risked certain torture or death if caught. Corporal Rubin provided not only food to the starving soldiers, but also desperately needed medical care and moral support for the sick and wounded of the POW camp. His brave, selfless efforts were directly attributed to saving the lives of as many as forty of his fellow prisoners.‚Äù
Rubin‚Äôs nephew, Robert Huntly, who was inspired by him to join the Army, described him as having a Hungarian accent and a Jackie Mason sense of humor.
Tibor ‚ÄúTed‚Äù Rubin, the only survivor of the Nazi genocide to earn the Medal of Honor, died in Garden Grove, California, on December 5, 2015.

author: TN Lifestyle Desk
title: Solar Eclipse 2024: Solar Eclipse 2024: Hindu Mythology Has The Perfect Explanation Why Rahu Attacks The Sun | Spirituality News - Times Now
text: Solar Eclipse 2024: Hindu Mythology Has The Perfect Explanation Why Rahu Attacks The Sun Solar eclipse is on April 8, 2024. As per the Hindu mythology, during this time the Rahu swallows the Sun. To know why Rahu seeks revenge from the Sun, read the story here. (Picture Credit: Canva) Solar eclipse (or Surya Grahan) holds a special significance in Hindu culture. It is said solar eclipses are said to have an impact on cosmic forces. This is why people tend to observe fast, take bath in holy rivers and perform prayers to reduce the negative impact of the eclipses. Solar eclipse is round the corner and is on April 8. It is said one should refrain from doing anything positive during this time to escape the effect of negative energies. From staying indoors, avoiding eating and drinking anything during the eclipse to devoting time to prayers, these are just some of the do‚Äôs and don‚Äôts one should observe during solar eclipses. As per the Hindu mythology, the story that goes around involves Rahu and Ketu, the two shadow planets. It is said that during Samudra Manthan (the churning of the ocean of milk), Rahu drank the nectar of immortality. Both Surya (the Sun) and Chandra (the Moon) on seeing demon Rahu drinking nectar in a disguised form alert Lord Vishnu, who was distributing the nectar in the avatar of Mohini. Enraged, Lord Vishnu beheaded Rahu through his sudarshan chakra. Since Rahu had already consumed a drop of nectar, his head (Rahu) became immortal while his body (Ketu) died. This explains why Rahu and Ketu keep seeking revenge from the Sun and the Moon from time to time. In fact, did you know our ancestors could even calculate the time of solar eclipses? As per the belief, Rahu and Ketu seek revenge on Sun and Moon, causing solar and lunar eclipses, respectively. Ever wondered why solar eclipses last for some time only? Well, even though Rahu swallows the Sun during a solar eclipse, but since it doesn‚Äôt have the body to digest it, the rays of the Sun shine bright on Earth again. Interesting, isn't it?
